text: Patient: So, the two medicines that you’ve got potential… Doctor: Yeah, yeah. Patient: What are the side effects? Doctor: Well, tiredness. Hi? Patient: Well, that was what? Doctor: Yes. Family Member: Xtandi. Patient: Xtandi. Doctor: That was Xtandi. So, tiredness. One of them has a low platelet issue. Like, you take it, and your platelets are gone. You stop it; the platelets come back. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You don’t feel bad from that, Patient: No.

text: Family Member 1: Do you do Zofran? Doctor: We do Zofran and we do Compazine. And then depending on the level of how much nausea you know. Family Member 1: Zofran works for me. I got pneumonia. Doctor: Well, you're right. And I think the important part here is that this is not a big nausea, type of chemo. There are some where you're like, “Okay, brace yourself, it's going to happen.” This is pretty mild. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It's actually called a mild emetogenic. So it just means it’s not gonna make you puke, but everybody's different. Patient: Oh, of course. Doctor: You know, so we want you to be ready. What I want is for that to be in your medicine cabinet. Family Member 1: If his gums are sensitive, can I call M___ too? Doctor: Yep, yes. And you know you could gargle with salt water to just keep that bacteria moving out of there. So there's no sort of overdose on warm saltwater. Family Member 1: How about hydrogen peroxide, diluted? Doctor: That's hard.

text: Patient: I know that, yes. Doctor: And you know that’s just a miserable status Patient: Yes. Yes. text: Patient: Okay, okay. But it never will go in remission, it will never be gone? Doctor: Well remission’s a tough word in cancer. Patient: I know. Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Remission would imply that everything is gone and when you have scans that are never going to be right, it’s hard for me to say you’re in remission. Patient: Sure, sure. Doctor: So we use words like response. You know are you having a good response? Is it a durable response? Is it a complete response? Patient: Okay. Doctor: And those are probably words that we opt to use. Um, If you have testicle cancer we could say remission Patient: Yeah. Doctor: because then you don’t see anything. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: There’s nothing in the blood work all your scans are clean, then you can say wow I see nothing Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Do you want me to step out for a few? Doctor: I just uh, you can stay, I mean it doesn’t matter to me. I did realize I wasn’t quite done because I had gone back to get paperwork. Healthcare Professional: Alright well I’ll step out. Doctor: Yeah like give me like two minutes, we’ll be set. Okay (door closes) Patient: Okay. (Pause 30 seconds) Doctor: Here you go. If you can sign here. Here you go. (sound of signing papers) Healthcare Professional 1: Sorry, just me. So I sent all your scripts (door closes) Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional 1: …electronically to the K____ pharmacy. Patient: Okay, thanks. Healthcare Professional 1: That’s your oxycodone, the Xanax and that the – this is the one to help you urinate. That’s Tamsulosin which is generic for Flomax. All your other medications, your vitamins, prednisone, your cholesterol medication, everything else.

text: Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: The super hormones for the three months also make you more tired, but not really that much more because once we lower your testosterone down to what we call castrate levels, to go from castrate to super castrate, people don’t complain about more tiredness. Patient: Right. Doctor: So um there are some things we watch and your blood tests to make sure you’re tolerating the drugs all right, but that’s not the big issue. Tiredness is the issue. So then we add chemo in and really we give the chemo to you four times on a Monday – Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - three weeks apart. Um, the the actual um chemo itself, you don’t get sick, you don’t throw up. We have all the medicines that stop that from happening. Anything that throw up We’re just really good at it. Uhm, Patient: Sure. Doctor: And during that time you’re more tired is when your blood counts are low when you’re fighting infection. So we ask you not to travel on a plane those four days, if at all possible. If you do you have to wear a mask, and we ask you not to be around babies for those four days if possible because they’re infectious, not that you’re an injury to them. Patient: Right. Doctor: But other than that uh there really are no side effects. You may lose your hair temporarily. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, um, but it grows back. Um and you generally will only lose it for the last two doses. Patient: Okay.

text: Family Member: Right. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So I’m fine with it. We fuss over big joints, hips, legs… Patient: Okay. Doctor: Shoulders because they can crack. Family Member: We were thinking it was right and not left. Patient: Yeah something to do with the hip replacement thought too. Doctor: Well the hip replacement always glows so then we always look for the other side to make sure that you don’t have a matching set. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: So the issue is if you start to feel it because you’re working more, or you’re lounging more, or doing whatever more up north and you’re aware, but it’s more of an awareness thing not we’re about to do this. Patient: Um hum, um hum. Doctor: People know and this is kind of like you know your right hip wasn’t functioning well before.

text: Family Member: He definitely has it? Doctor: Right. If it's bad enough where you can't button, your shirt or you're constantly dropping things- Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: -or you're burning yourself or you're tripping all the time, that- Patient: My neuropathy is xxx. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. And you know, are you are you falling? Patient: No. Doctor: So those are things where it's like, oh, this is bad, but it's a fine line where it could be bad. So we will obsess about how are you doing? You know, is there any change? So, those are one of the things that we would check, but we give the same attention on the trial as well as off the trial. You know, if you're getting this regular chemo anyways, we'd ask you the same obsessive questions- Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: How are your feet or your hands. You know what your quality of life, are you losing too much weight, you know, is it too rapid of a weight loss? Are you- you know most people are not nauseous and they don’t throw up, but there's always one in a group you know- are you having problems with that or are your bowels, so we would go down the line like that like we do for Xtandi. And of course now that Xtandi's not working, stop the Xtandi because it's just losses you know kind of drive at the moment, but it's something to consider for later, so we do sometimes go back. Family Member: You're saying Xtandi- Doctor: Mhmm. Family Member: -so he would continue to take the Xtandi along with the chemo?

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: If the decision says the insurance will cover it, after you’ve read it, huh, you could say, yeah, I’m interested. And then we’ll bring you back to have a formal discussion about what that looks like. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so all that can happen in the next three to four weeks. Huh, so you come off the abiraterone. We’ll see if this gets better. Watch your potassium. But you do some reading. Huh, if there’s other people you want to talk about the trial, people that have been on it, huh, or have any concerns about, you know, being here so much, let us know, because we can work on some of that with you. Patient: Now, the only thing, huh, mainly. The vitamin C, if I get it, I might not use something, and if I don’t get it, it ain’t going to affect the chemo I’m getting to try to do-? Doctor: Right. Because that’s what everybody gets. That’s what everybody gets. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay? Patient: So. You know. Doctor: Yeah. It ends up boiling down to your time on this study. And again, someone close by or regional, it, it makes some sense, you know, huh, and you could always back out if it’s just too crazy to come in. You know? We’re are going to try to get you at least the first cycle of this to sort of get the data on you about side effects, what you’re feeling, what you’re not feeling, huh, and that. Huh, so it sounds to me like you’re open to the idea. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But we don’t have to commit today to sort of say, yeah, I’m doing it, huh, because we also have to check your insurance. Patient: Right.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: We’re all like crazy mad scientists in the back. Go, here’s what I, look, that’s what we like to do but with prostate cancer every time we do that it doesn’t behave. It either does nothing but give you more side effects or it just causes a problem. You know, like if you combine this with Zytiga you get more fractures. That’s no good. Patient: Right, I remember you saying that at one of our visits you were saying that. Doctor: Yeah and so just because theoretically like well, they should kind of work together. Patient: Right, Right. Doctor: It just doesn’t so we learned most of the drugs in prostate cancer it’s not like the other cancers where you do two or three drugs together. You know, we’re kind of like the loner group so it’s one at a time, sequence matters with one. Family Member: So this other doctor is going to explain the side effects he may get from radiation? Doctor: Yeah, so when you see Dr. B____, so that’s another Dr. B, you’re going to listen about what can or can’t you do, why is it once a month, what are your obligations. What are the potential side effects and how does he want to see you and he might need blood work kind of not on day of because there’s a half-life to the medicine as in if he knows the week before your counts are good to go then he can order it and when you show up it’s here and you get it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If he orders it and you show up and uh-oh you can’t get it, there’s, we’re in trouble. Patient: Right, Okay. Doctor: That’s fifteen thousand you might have to just flush down the toilet because you can’t save it for the next week because it starts to decay and you can’t give it to somebody else so. Patient: Okay, I’m good with that. That sounds good. Okay?

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
